item.title: Conversation Starters
item.description:
Arabic Conversation Starters

A list of simple Arabic phrases to help break into a conversation with an Arabic speaker.

  • Ø£ÙÙ†ÙØ§ Ø£ÙØªÙÙƒÙÙ„Ù‘ÙÙ…Ù Ù±Ù„Ù„Ù‘ÙØºÙØ©Ù Ù±Ù„Ù’Ø¹ÙØ±ÙØ¨ÙÙŠÙ‘ÙØ©Ù ÙˆÙÙ„ÙÙ°ÙƒÙÙ†Ù’ Ø¨ÙØ¨ÙØ·Ù’Ø¡Ù ÙˆÙÙÙØµÙ’Ø­ÙÙ‰ ÙÙÙ‚ÙØ·Ù’
    I speak Arabic, but slowly and only in formal Arabic.

  • ÙƒÙÙŠÙ’ÙÙ Ø­ÙØ§Ù„ÙÙƒÙØŸ
    How are you?

  • Ù…ÙØ§ Ù±Ø³Ù’Ù…ÙÙƒÙØŸ
    What is your name?

  • Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ Ø£ÙÙŠÙ’Ù†Ù Ø£ÙÙ†Ù’ØªÙØŸ
    Where are you from?

    May I talk to you?

item.title: Grammar Terminology
item.description:
Arabic Grammar Terms and Structure

This section introduces essential Arabic Grammar (Ù†Ø­Ùˆ Ø¹Ø±Ø¨ÙŠ) terms, grouped into clear categories. Each term is listed with its Arabic equivalent and a concise explanation.

ğŸŸ¦ Sentence Structure

English Term Arabic Term Explanation
Verbal Sentence Ø¬ÙÙ…Ù’Ù„ÙØ© ÙÙØ¹Ù’Ù„ÙÙŠÙ‘ÙØ© A sentence beginning with a verb. Structure: Verb â†’ Subject â†’ Object.
Nominal Sentence Ø¬ÙÙ…Ù’Ù„ÙØ© Ø§ÙØ³Ù’Ù…ÙÙŠÙ‘ÙØ© A sentence beginning with a noun. Structure: Subject (Ù…Ø¨ØªØ¯Ø£) â†’ Predicate (Ø®Ø¨Ø±).
Subject Ù…ÙØ¨Ù’ØªÙØ¯ÙØ£ÙŒ The topic of a nominal sentence.
Predicate Ø®ÙØ¨ÙØ±ÙŒ What is said about the subject in a nominal sentence.
Object Ù…ÙÙÙ’Ø¹ÙÙˆÙ„ÙŒ Ø¨ÙÙ‡Ù The noun receiving the action in a verbal sentence.

ğŸŸ¨ Parts of Speech

English Term Arabic Term Explanation
Noun Ø§ÙØ³Ù’Ù…ÙŒ A word that refers to a person, place, thing, or idea.
Verb ÙÙØ¹Ù’Ù„ÙŒ A word that shows an action or occurrence.
Adjective ØµÙÙÙØ©ÙŒ Describes a noun; matches in gender, number, and case.
Adverb Ø¸ÙØ±Ù’ÙÙŒ Modifies a verb or adjective (e.g., quickly, yesterday).
Pronoun Ø¶ÙÙ…ÙÙŠØ±ÙŒ Replaces a noun (e.g., he, she, it, we).
Active Participle Ø§ÙØ³Ù’Ù…Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’ÙÙØ§Ø¹ÙÙ„Ù Describes the doer of an action (e.g., ÙƒÙØ§ØªÙØ¨ = writer).
Passive Participle Ø§ÙØ³Ù’Ù…Ù Ø§Ù„Ù’Ù…ÙÙÙ’Ø¹ÙÙˆÙ„Ù Describes the one who the action is done to (e.g., Ù…ÙÙƒÙ’ØªÙÙˆØ¨ = written).

ğŸŸ© Verb Tenses and Moods

English Term Arabic Term Explanation
Past Tense Ø§Ù„Ù’Ù…ÙØ§Ø¶ÙÙŠ Indicates a completed action.
Present Tense Ø§Ù„Ù’Ù…ÙØ¶ÙØ§Ø±ÙØ¹Ù Indicates an ongoing or habitual action.
Imperative / Command Ø§Ù„Ù’Ø£ÙÙ…Ù’Ø±Ù Used to give orders or requests.
Jussive Mood Ø§Ù„Ù’Ù…ÙØ¬Ù’Ø²ÙÙˆÙ…Ù Used after particles like lam (Ù„ÙÙ…) or li (Ù„ÙÙ€); removes final vowel.
Active Voice Ù…ÙØ¹Ù’Ø±ÙÙˆÙÙŒ The subject performs the action.
Passive Voice Ù…ÙØ¬Ù’Ù‡ÙÙˆÙ„ÙŒ The action is done to the subject.

ğŸŸ¥ Cases and Declension

English Term Arabic Term Explanation
Nominative Case Ø§Ù„Ù’Ù…ÙØ±Ù’ÙÙÙˆØ¹Ù Typically for subjects; marked with á¸ammah (Ù€Ù).
Accusative Case Ø§Ù„Ù’Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ØµÙÙˆØ¨Ù For objects or adverbs; marked with fatá¸¥ah (Ù€Ù).
Genitive Case Ø§Ù„Ù’Ù…ÙØ¬Ù’Ø±ÙÙˆØ±Ù Used after prepositions or in iá¸Äfah; marked with kasrah (Ù€Ù).
Declinable Noun Ù…ÙØ¹Ù’Ø±ÙØ¨ÙŒ A noun whose ending changes based on grammatical position.
Fully Declinable Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ØµÙØ±ÙÙÙŒ Accepts all case endings and tanwÄ«n.
Partially Declinable ØºÙÙŠÙ’Ø±Ù Ù…ÙÙ†Ù’ØµÙØ±ÙÙÙ Does not take tanwÄ«n and is limited in case endings.
Indeclinable Noun Ù…ÙØ¨Ù’Ù†ÙÙŠÙ‘ÙŒ A noun whose form remains fixed.

ğŸŸª Possession (Iá¸Äfah)

English Term Arabic Term Explanation
Possessed Word Ù…ÙØ¶ÙØ§ÙÙŒ The item owned; the first part of an iá¸Äfah phrase.
Possessor (of the item) Ù…ÙØ¶ÙØ§ÙÙŒ Ø¥ÙÙ„ÙÙŠÙ’Ù‡Ù The owner; always in the genitive case.

item.title: Imperative
item.description:
Imperative Form in Arabic (Ø§Ù„Ø£Ù…Ø±)

Rules for Regular Verbs

  1. Middle letter with fatá¸¥a (Ù€ÙÙ€) or kasra (Ù€ÙÙ€) â†’ Imperative starts with Ø¥Ù
  2. Middle letter with á¸amma (Ù€ÙÙ€) â†’ Imperative starts with Ø£Ù

Examples:

Verb (Past) Present (You masc.) Imperative (You masc.) Notes

Plural Forms of Ø±ÙÙƒÙØ¨Ù:

item.title: About Me
item.description:
Seasoned Staff Engineer with a passion to learn new skills both technical and non-technical!

Visit the linkedin profile!

item.title: Resume
item.description:
About me

As a Staff Engineer with extensive software development experience in the semi-conductor and telecom industry, I have a proven track record of leading product development. I have worked as a team member and as an individual contributor handling applications or software modules single handedly.

I have a broad range of experience with extensive development in C, C++, C# and scripting languages on Windows and Linux platforms. I have taken on various roles in the semi-conductor and telecom sectors.

item.title: Hello World!
item.description: I’ve wanted to put a page on github for a while and finally here it is!

git push origin main -f

Hugo Command

item.title: Banana Pi HomeCloud
item.description:
Refresh MiniDLNA

MiniDLNA couldn’t find any new files in my media_dir even though I was adding new files. I think the problem was that my media_dir was set to an external hard drive.

(media_dir=v,/media/ExtHD/x/x). I got it working, here are the steps I used to fix.

sudo service minidlna stop sudo rm -rf /var/cache/minidlna/* sudo nano /etc/minidlna.conf

  • Set the media_dir back to default location - media_dir=V,/var/lib/minidlna/video
  • Create a link in /var/lib/minidlna to the directory you want monitored.

sudo ln -s /media/ExtHD/video /var/lib/minidlna/videos sudo service minidlna force-reload

item.title: Raspberry Pi
item.description:
Setup

Steps I followed to set-up my raspberry Pi with Raspbian

Also configure -

  • XBMC (for playing videos)
  • NFS (to access external hard drive from any device in the house)
  • VNC viewer (to access the desktop from any device in the house)

Format SD Card

  • Windows
  1. Download SD Formatter https://www.sdcard.org/downloads/formatter_4/
  2. Install SD Formatter and run the software
  3. Set “FORMAT SIZE ADJUSTMENT” to ON in the Options menu.
  4. Make sure you have selected the Drive your SD Card is inserted in
  5. Format the memory card
  • Linux
  1. Use gparted (or the command-line version parted if you prefer), if you don’t have it, install it as you usually would.
  2. Format the entire disk as FAT / FAT16 (make sure you select the correct disk)

Install OS

NOOBS

All things Technology

Plan to move blogs from blogger to github, for now these are here

Visit the github profile!

item.title: Sid's Chicken Curry
item.description:
Most of what I see is forgotten.
Most of what I think never makes it out of my head.
Most of what I say disappears into the air not long after I say it.

“Silence is golden”â€”but sometimes, a few of those thoughts or words might be worth capturing. Like that half-written recipe or a fleeting idea. Maybe itâ€™ll help someone out there. Maybe it’ll help me when I stumble across it again.
